abstract.p: Asks RP’s help in procuring a specimen of a real Irish rabbit, L. veomicule [Lepus vermicula]?.

div.p: I am going to beg a great and troublesome favor of you,—I have been collecting skeletons of all varieties of Rabbits, & I want very much a real Irish Rabbit, the L. veomicule of our poor friend Thompson— Would you have the great kindness to take the trouble to procure me one. The only care requisite to be to get one not very severely shot, but especially not struck on the back of the head to kill it, as that part is easily injured & is very characteristic.

I enclose an address; and you will know whether to steamer to Liverpool & then per Railway, will be the cheapest and quickest route— I am fearful you will think me rather unreasonable in begging this favor.
Truly believe me | My dear Sir | Yours sincerely | CH. DARWIN

div.note: The date as given by Praeger 1935.

In a note dated 7 March 1857 (DAR 45: 76), CD recorded that: ‘Irish Rabbit in Brit. Mus is named Lepus vermicula of Thompson.— so marked var.’ In his continuation of William Thompson’s work on Irish natural history (see n. 3, below), Patterson classified this rabbit as Lepus cuniculus (Thompson 1849–56, 4: 30). Lepus vermicula and L. cuniculus are synonyms of Oryctolagus cuniculus subsp. cuniculus.

Thompson, who had died in 1851, had specified in his will that his manuscript and notes for the remaining volume of his Natural history of Ireland were to be given to Patterson and James R. Garrett to prepare for publication. After Garrett’s death in 1855, Patterson assumed the task and published volume four in 1856.
